title: debounce().pending() not part of last release
body:
Hey,
there is a debounced.pending() check if i look in the [master branch](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/blame/2f79053d7bc7c9c9561a30dda202b3dcd2b72b90/debounce.js#L209), which has been [merged back in 2017](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/pull/3388).

title: Add 'pickArray' function

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Added a function which picks an object property from every object in an array.

Example:

```js
const arr = [
  { 'a': 1, 'b': 2 },
  { 'a': 1, 'b': 3 },
  { 'a': 2, 'b': 4 }
]
pickArray(arr, 'a')
// => [1, 1, 2]
```

Also works with nested arrays:

```js
const arr = [[1, 2], [1, 3], [2, 4]]
pickArray(arr, 0)
// => [1, 1, 2]
```

title: isMatch not work with nested objects?

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
Hi, 
maybe I misunderstand the doc. IsMatch can work with nested object?

I try to explain myself:
I have these two objects with many properties (there are a lot I cannot paste here the whole object) in my application.
The structure is like this:
```
{
id: string,
value: string,
active: boolean,
detail: { name: string, attributes: any[], ...   }
}
```

At first the two objects are a deep clone of each other (I use cloneDeep). 
After that the user can modify the second one, while the application keep the first to permit an easy cancel operation.

At the moment my app permit only to modify one property, a boolean (active).
If I use IsMatch after a change the result is always false, no matter if I restore the previous value of the boolean.

However, If I use isMatchWith and exclude "detail" from the comparison (retun true if the key is 'detail') than the match work.
I do not touch detail (for now) and I double check it.

Is it a limit of "isMatch" that compare the nested property by reference and not by value? There are alternatives?

Nothing else changed within my repo, so it made sense to reach out here.

title: Unexpected behavior by isEqual when comparing objects with undefined values

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I observed some strange behavior with `isEqual`, and I'd like to clarify if this is the intended functionality or is it a bug.

Consider the following snippet:

```javascript
const _ = require('lodash');

console.log('{} === {} evaluates to', {} === {});
console.log('{} === {key: undefined} evaluates to', {} === {key: undefined});
console.log('_.isEqual({}, {}) evaluates to', _.isEqual({}, {}));
console.log('_.isEqual({}, {key: undefined}) evaluates to', _.isEqual({}, {key: undefined}));
```

The output is

```
{} === {} evaluates to false
{} === {key: undefined} evaluates to false
_.isEqual({}, {}) evaluates to true       
_.isEqual({}, {key: undefined}) evaluates to false
```

I would have expected that `isEqual` would either emulate the same functionality as `===` when comparing simple objects with no nesting, or it would emulate comparing the serialized representation of the arguments.

However, when comparing `{}` and `{}`, `isEqual` behaves like comparing the serialized representation of `{}` and `{}` (since `JSON.stringify()` would return the same string for both), but when comparing `{}` and `{key: undefined}`, this is not true (since `JSON.stringify()` would return the same string for both in this case as well), and it behaves like `===` instead.

Is this strange behavior expected? Is it documented somewhere?

title: Merge lodash-es into lodash package

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
I think the preferred way to use lodash is to use one of the following statements:

```js
import { pick } from 'lodash';
const { pick } = require('lodash');
```

However, there are some issues with this. This is caused by the fact that the `main` entry of the `lodash` package refers to a UMD bundle.

- This can’t be tree shaken, meaning all of lodash is included in a lot of websites out there.
- This doesn’t work with modules (`.mjs` files) in NodeJS. Instead, lodash needs to be imported as a default import.

I believe both issues would be resolved if the `lodash-es` package is merged into the `lodash` package, but with every file using an `.mjs` extension instead of a `.js` extension.

I’m aware this doubles the package size, but it greatly reduces the bundle size when used with module bundlers, where package size matters most.

This will remove the need for special tooling such as `lodash-webpack-plugin`, `babel-plugin-lodash`, or special other special configurations.

I believe this is non-breaking and could be released as a minor version, so existing users will find their bundle sizes to be reduced by a lot without even knowing.

For lodash 5, CommonJS support could even be dropped, fully removing the need for a build process. This aligns with more users moving pushing towards ESM, i.e. [sindresorhus](https://github.com/sindresorhus/meta/discussions/15) and [xdm](https://github.com/wooorm/xdm)

title: toNumber (comma separator)
body:
Hi,
Great library! Thanks!
Continuing #3027 in a different angle.

### Expected Behaviour
```js
_.toNumber('3,200') => 3200
```

### Actual Behaviour
```js
_.toNumber('3,200') => NaN
```

### Workaround
```js
_.toNumber(_.replace('3,200', /,/g, ''))
```

I think it should handle this case internally

title: [BUG] _.orderBy inconsistent

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
```javascript
_.orderBy([{x: "foo"}, {x: Infinity}], 'x'); // [ { x: 'foo' }, { x: Infinity } ]
_.orderBy([{x: Infinity}, {x: "foo"}], 'x'); // [ { x: Infinity }, { x: 'foo' } ]

["foo", Infinity].sort() // [ Infinity, 'foo' ]
[Infinity, "foo"].sort() // [ Infinity, 'foo' ]
```

https://262.ecma-international.org/5.1/#sec-15.4.4.11

title: Update to actions/setup-node@v2
body:
I propose that this project updates the `actions/setup-node` version used in their GitHub Actions CI.

`actions/setup-node` is stable as of version 2.14, using the `v2` tag will point to the latest `v2` release.
See the change-logs for the `v2` release line at https://github.com/actions/setup-node/releases

title: Update to actions/setup-node@v2

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
## Changes:

- Use version 2 of `actions/setup-node`

## Context:

`actions/setup-node` is stable as of version 2.14, using the `v2` tag will point to the latest `v2` release.
See the change-logs for the `v2` release line at https://github.com/actions/setup-node/releases

title: Document release process

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body: There are a lot of intricacies in working with lodash-cli, which does a lot of regex magic to split the monolithic lodash.js file into separate files. This needs to be documented so we can reduce the bus factor of lodash, and ensure that releases are not broken (like the stretch of releases from v4.17.16 to v4.17.18).

title: Prevent command injection through the variable option

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
This fixes the issue disclosed at https://app.snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-LODASH-1040724

For now, I used a regexp allowing any ES5 identifier for the variable name. The advantage of that is that it avoids BC breaks if some code uses weird variable names. The drawback is that the regexp is big.
If reducing the range of allowed variable names is OK, a smaller regex could be used.

title: Pick shows strange behavior for missing properties
body:
Works:
```
pick({ a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 }, ['a', 'c'])
```
Doesn't work:
```
pick({ a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 }, ['a', 'd'])
```
Expected behavior: return { a: 1 }

title: filter: docs seem incomplete + return value seems wrong for objects
body:
Looking at the docs for filter (https://devdocs.io/lodash~4/index#filter), I can't tell what gets returned if I pass an object to the function. The docs say that "the new filtered array" is returned. Array of what? Values? Keys? Both? I had to resort to trial and error to figure out that it's an array of values.

In addition to a docs update, the example below the docs could be updated to show how this works for collections.

The other issue is something that probably won't get fixed, since it would break backwards compatibility, but the return value for objects seems wrong. Shouldn't filtering an object give you an object in return? If you only want the values, you can easily call `values()` on that result. The current approach is removing data that could be really useful in certain situations.

title: feat: import lodash from lodash/fp.js

labels.name: issue bankruptcy
labels.description: Closing the issue/PR to start fresh

body:
To support bundlers with minifying and tree-shaking the fp.js should
import the package by its name instead of the minified version.

This will enable a few optimisations in modern bundlers:

- Tracking the usage of functions (e.g. to allow proper tree-shaking)
- Allowing to override the package (e.g. with webpack alias or
  externals)

Otherwise we might end up in a situation like this #3079

title: Different source code in master and 4.17.20 release branches
startCase separates acronym
body:
I have a string that includes an acronym. The acronym is pluralized and it is causing a space to be added inappropriately.
The string: "otherACRs"
Intended output: "Other ACRs"
Actual output: "Other AC Rs"

Is there a technical limitation here or is there an opportunity for this function to be improved to accommodate a case like this?

title: _.every provides incorrect arguments to predicate when called on object with "length" key
body:
When `_.every` is called on an object which contains a key labeled `length` which has an integer value, the predicate seems to be called with `value = undefined` and `key = 0`. This can be seen in the following example:
```
_.every({length: 1}, (value, key) => {
    console.log(value)
    console.log(key)
    return true
})
```
The above logs `undefined` and `0`, though it correctly returns `true`. Additionally, if other keys are added to the object, the `console.log` is seemingly only called once. This can be seen in the following example:
```
_.every({length: 1, foo: "bar"}, (value, key) => {
    console.log(value)
    console.log(key)
    return true
})
```
The above again logs `undefined` and `0` and correctly returns `true`.
